importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, highlighting a significant advancement in the nation's space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The launch of the H1 satellite in 2025 represents a pivotal moment in Pakistan's space program, signaling a growing national commitment to space-based technology for development and security.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, into orbit from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre.
The satellite was launched by Pakistan’s Space Agency, SUPARCO, on October 19, 2025.
Hyperspectral satellites can detect subtle chemical or material changes on the ground, enabling advanced applications in agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster management.
The satellite is expected to significantly enhance Pakistan’s capabilities in precision agriculture, urban planning, and geohazard risk identification.
The launch is seen as a major step forward in Pakistan’s space program and reflects its strategic partnership with China.
The H1 satellite is part of a broader trend of Pakistan launching three satellites into orbit this year, including the fully operational EO-1 and KS-1 satellites.
It may take about two months to calibrate the H1 satellite’s systems before it becomes fully operational.
The mission supports national development goals, including those of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), by improving infrastructure planning and natural resource management.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The primary actor in the article, as Pakistan is the nation that launched its first hyperspectral satellite, marking a major milestone in its space program.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agency responsible for the design, launch, and management of Pakistan’s hyperspectral satellite H1, and central to the country’s space development efforts.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The key technological achievement of the article, enabling advanced Earth observation for agriculture, disaster response, and environmental monitoring.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A satellite launch facility in China’s northwest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location from which the H1 satellite was launched, highlighting the international cooperation between Pakistan and China in space missions.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China hosted the launch of Pakistan’s H1 satellite, underscoring a strategic space partnership between the two countries.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development initiative linking China’s Xinjiang to Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite’s capabilities are expected to support CPEC by enabling better urban planning and risk assessment along the corridor’s route.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other satellites launched by Pakistan this year
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are fully operational, showing Pakistan’s broader progress in its space program and providing context for H1’s significance as a new addition.

namedEntities.name: Muhammad Yousuf Khan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided a key statement about the satellite’s potential to revolutionize agriculture and natural resource management.

namedEntities.name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs – Pakistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The foreign affairs department of Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It publicly confirmed the significance of the launch and emphasized the strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, marking a major milestone in its space program. Developed and managed by SUPARCO, the H1 satellite is equipped with hyperspectral imaging technology capable of detecting subtle material changes on Earth’s surface, which will enhance national capabilities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster risk assessment. The mission is part of Pakistan’s broader push to expand its space capabilities, with two other satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) already operational. The launch strengthens Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China and supports key development initiatives such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) by improving infrastructure planning and natural resource management. Although full operational status will take about two months to achieve, the satellite is expected to revolutionize agricultural productivity and climate resilience in Pakistan.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
